Testing is an important means to ensure software quality. Tagtag project adopts a multi-layered testing strategy, including unit testing, integration testing, and API testing. This document will detail the testing methods, tools, and best practices for the Tagtag project.
The testing in Tagtag project is divided into the following layers:
: Verify that the code implements the expected functionality
: Discover potential problems and defects through testing
: Tests can serve as documentation for the code, facilitating subsequent maintenance
: Automated testing is the foundation of continuous integration
: Prevent introducing new issues when modifying code
Tagtag backend is developed using Java language and uses JUnit 5 and Mockito for testing.
Unit testing is the testing of a single class or function to verify its behavior in an isolated environment.
: Java mocking framework used to mock dependent objects
: Fluent assertion library that provides a better assertion experience
Unit test files are usually placed in the same package as the tested class, located in the

src
└── main
    └── java
        └── dev
            └── tagtag
                └── module
                    └── system
                        └── service
                            └── impl
                                └── PostServiceImpl.java
└── test
    └── java
        └── dev
            └── tagtag
                └── module
                    └── system
                        └── service
                            └── impl
                                └── PostServiceImplTest.java
language-java shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
: Each test method should test only one functional point
: Test names should describe the functionality and expected result being tested
: Use Mockito to mock external dependencies, avoiding test interference from external factors
: Test null values, boundary values, exception cases, etc.
: Test code should be concise, clear, and easy to understand
Integration testing is the testing of multiple modules to verify that the interaction between modules is correct.
: In-memory database used for testing database operations
Integration test files are usually placed in the same directory as unit tests, but require the
: Integration tests should use real dependency relationships, not Mocks
: Use H2 or other in-memory databases to avoid affecting real databases
annotation to ensure test data does not contaminate the database
: Integration tests should test core business processes, not individual functional points
API testing is the testing of REST APIs to verify the correctness and reliability of interfaces.
: Test GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc. all HTTP methods
: Test different query parameters, path parameters, and request bodies
: Test invalid parameters, insufficient permissions, and other error cases
: Verify response status codes, headers, and response body format
: Use JSON Schema to validate the structure of the response body
Tagtag frontend is developed using TypeScript language and uses Vitest and Cypress for testing.
Frontend unit testing is the testing of a single component or function to verify its behavior in an isolated environment.
: Modern frontend testing framework based on Vite
Frontend unit test files are usually placed in the same directory as the tested component, using

src
└── views
    └── modules
        └── system
            └── post
                ├── index.vue
                ├── FormModal.vue
                └── __tests__
                    ├── index.test.ts
                    └── FormModal.test.ts
language-typescript shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
should open modal when add button is clicked
: Verify that components can render correctly
: Test component responses to user interactions
: Verify that component props and emits work correctly
: Use vi.mock to mock external dependencies
: Verify the behavior of computed properties and watch
Frontend integration testing is the testing of multiple components to verify that the interaction between components is correct.
: Same testing framework as unit tests
: API mocking library used to mock backend APIs
// Mock gridApi.refresh() to trigger data loading
// More detailed verification can be added based on actual implementation
: Verify communication and data transfer between components
: Use MSW to mock backend APIs, avoiding dependency on real backend
: Test complete flows from user input to data update
: Verify the behavior of Pinia state management
E2E (End-to-End) testing is the testing of the entire application to verify end-to-end user flows.
E2E test files are usually placed in the
: Test the most commonly used core flows by users
: Use real test data, avoid using hard-coded test data
: Each test should be independent and not depend on the results of other tests
: Encapsulate page operations as page objects to improve test maintainability
: Set reasonable timeout based on network conditions and application performance
Security testing is an important component of frontend testing, focusing on XSS, CSRF, and other security vulnerabilities.
XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) is one of the most common frontend security vulnerabilities. Here are examples of XSS protection testing:
// Not recommended - directly render user input
// Recommended - use DOMPurify for HTML sanitization
// Not recommended - use v-html to render user input
// Verify javascript: protocol is removed or escaped
// Verify safe HTML tags are preserved
CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) is another common security vulnerability. Here are examples of CSRF protection testing:
// Not recommended - no CSRF Token protection
// Recommended - use axios interceptor to automatically add CSRF Token
should include CSRF token in request headers
// Verify request headers contain CSRF Token
Sensitive information leakage is another important aspect of frontend security. Here are examples of sensitive information protection testing:
// Not recommended - store sensitive information in localStorage
// Recommended - use sessionStorage or memory storage
// Backend sets Cookie: Set-Cookie: authToken=xxx; HttpOnly; Secure; SameSite=Strict
// Not recommended - pass sensitive information in URL
// Recommended - use route parameters or state management
// Sensitive information leakage test case examples
should not store token in localStorage
Performance testing is an important means to ensure application response speed and user experience.
// Must fix: performance issue - unnecessary re-renders // Not recommended // Recommended - use virtual scrolling // Recommended - use v-once for static content
// Must fix: performance issue - unnecessary re-renders
// Recommended - use v-once for static content
// Verify rendering time is within reasonable range (e.g., 100ms)
// Not recommended - event listeners not cleaned up
// Recommended - clean up event listeners when component is destroyed
should clean up event listeners on unmount
: Each test should test only one functional point
: Don't Repeat Yourself, avoid duplicate test code
Independent: Tests should be independent of each other
Repeatable: Test results should be repeatable
Self-validating: Tests should automatically validate results
Timely: Tests should be written in a timely manner
: Test coverage for core functionality should reach above 80%
Line coverage: The percentage of code lines executed by tests out of total code lines
Branch coverage: The percentage of branches executed by tests out of total branches
Function coverage: The percentage of functions executed by tests out of total functions
Statement coverage: The percentage of statements executed by tests out of total statements
: Developers execute tests during local development
: Tests are automatically executed during continuous integration
: Complete test suites are executed regularly
: Specific test cases are executed as needed
: Use tools to generate visual test reports
: Regularly analyze test results to identify issues and improvement points
: Share test reports with team members
: Continuously improve test strategies and code quality based on test reports
Tagtag project uses GitHub Actions for continuous integration to automatically execute tests.
: GitHub Actions automatically triggers the CI process
: Execute unit tests, integration tests, and API tests
: If tests pass, deploy the application to the test environment
language-yaml shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main, develop ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main, develop ]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    
    - name: Set up JDK 17
      uses: actions/setup-java@v3
      with:
        java-version: '17'
        distribution: 'temurin'
        cache: maven
    
    - name: Build with Maven
      run: mvn -B package --file pom.xml
    
    - name: Run tests
      run: mvn test
    
    - name: Upload test results
      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
      with:
        name: test-results
        path: tagtag-*/target/surefire-reports/

Testing is an important means to ensure software quality. Tagtag project adopts a multi-layered testing strategy, including unit testing, integration testing, and API testing. By following testing best practices and using appropriate testing tools, we can improve code quality, reduce regression issues, support continuous integration, and ensure the long-term stable development of the project.
We hope this document can help developers understand the testing methods and best practices of the Tagtag project, write high-quality test cases, and jointly maintain a high-quality codebase.
